head.headtext: Insurance against liability and benefits available to the injured party

para.paratext: Fed. R. Evid. 411 and O.C.G.A. § 24-4-411 provide that, in all civil proceedings involving a claim for damages, evidence that a person had or did not have liability insurance is not admissible to prove negligence. Georgia's Code section codifies prior Georgia case law, which was consistent with federal practice. Exclusion is not required for evidence of insurance against liability in proceedings under Code § 40-1-112 or when such evidence is offered for a relevant purpose such as proof of agency, ownership, or control, and the court finds that the danger of unfair prejudice is substantially outweighed by the probative value of the evidence.

In the first case addressing Rule 411, the Court of Appeals in Brown v. Tucker[1] upheld the admission of limited evidence that another passenger had received a letter from the tortfeasor's insurance company to settle her claim against the tortfeasor, but had not settled her claim against a third party regarding the same accident. The court performed a balancing act and determined that the evidence was admissible for the relevant purpose of the witness's credibility, and that the probative value of the evidence substantially outweighed the prejudice of having the jury possibly assume that the tortfeasor was insured.
Brown v. Tucker, 337 Ga. App. 704, 788 S.E.2d 810 (2016).
